title: AB 1303
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 65961 of the Government Code in California is amended. Section 65961 of the Government Code in California is amended to restrict cities and counties from imposing certain conditions on building permits for residential units within five years of subdivision approval. The amended Section 65961 of the Government Code in California prohibits cities and counties from imposing additional conditions on building permits for residential units after the subdivision approval. The amended Section 65961 of the Government Code in California prohibits cities and counties from imposing additional conditions on building permits for residential units after subdivision approval. However, they are not prohibited from taking certain actions. The amended Section 65961 of the Government Code in California prohibits cities and counties from imposing additional conditions on building permits for residential units after subdivision approval. However, they can impose conditions or requirements for health and safety reasons or to comply with state or federal law. They can also withhold or refuse to issue a building permit if necessary for legal compliance. The amended Section 65961 of the Government Code in California prohibits cities and counties from imposing additional conditions on building permits for residential units after subdivision approval. They can impose conditions for health and safety reasons or to comply with state or federal law, including withholding building permits if necessary for legal compliance. The amended Section 65961 of the Government Code in California prohibits cities and counties from imposing additional conditions on building permits for residential units after subdivision approval. This section also applies to newly incorporated cities or city and counties that include areas from a tentative or parcel map. Conditions imposed by the county before incorporation are still applicable under this section. When a city incorporates areas from a tentative or parcel map, conditions imposed by the county before incorporation remain applicable. The five-year period for a tentative subdivision map or parcel map extension is reduced to three years. Section 66452.25 allows cities, counties, or city and counties to levy fees or conditions for tentative subdivision maps or parcel maps extensions. Section 66452.25 of the Government Code allows for a 24-month extension of tentative maps, vesting tentative maps, or parcel maps approved in certain counties between January 1, 2002, and July 11, 2013. If a map was approved within a specific county, the expiration time can be extended by 24 months upon application of the subdivider, as long as it meets zoning and general plan requirements. The expiration time of a map approved on or before December 31, 2001, can be extended by 24 months if it meets zoning and general plan requirements. If not consistent, the extension may be denied or conditionally approved. The legislative body or advisory agency may deny or conditionally approve an extension for a period of 24 months if the map is not consistent with zoning and general plan requirements. An approved tentative map can be automatically extended for 60 days or until the extension application is approved, conditionally approved, or denied. If an extension is denied by the advisory agency, the subdivider can appeal to the legislative body within 15 days. Upon application by the subdivider to extend an approved tentative map, it shall be automatically extended for 60 days or until the extension application is approved, conditionally approved, or denied. If the advisory agency denies the extension, the subdivider can appeal to the legislative body within 15 days. In a county, this section applies if the annual mean household income is less than 80% of the statewide annual mean income based on the American Community Survey. The county qualifies for this section if its annual mean household income is less than 80% of the statewide annual mean income, as per the American Community Survey. Additionally, the annual nonseasonal unemployment rate must be at least 2.75% higher than the statewide rate, based on the Labor Market Review report. The community revitalization plan requires the annual nonseasonal unemployment rate to be 2.75% higher than the statewide rate and the poverty rate to be at least 4% higher than the statewide median. The population for whom poverty status is determined must be at least 4 percent higher than the statewide median poverty rate, based on the American Community Survey. This extension is in addition to any other expiration date extensions provided in specific sections. The extension provided by subdivisions (a) and (b) is in addition to any expiration date extensions in specific sections. Any approval by a state agency for a development project included in a map extended under subdivisions (a) and (b) shall be extended by 24 months. The provisions of Section 65961 regarding conditions for building permits for residential subdivisions are modified for tentative maps extended under this section. This act is an urgency statute for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, or safety and shall go into immediate effect. This act is an urgency statute to preserve development applications set to expire due to adverse economic conditions in the construction industry.
